awd_titl_txt: MSB-FRA Modeling Invasion Dynamics Across Scales (MIDAS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Invasions by exotic species pose a major threat to nearly all ecosystems.  In fact, about 40 percent of U.S. forests have been invaded by exotic plants, resulting in significant economic loss (over $100 billion annually) and ecological damages.  Unfortunately, current understanding of large scale invasion patterns and distribution processes is still limited.  This project, Modeling Invasion Dynamics Across Scales (MIDAS), seeks to understand how the underlying biological, geophysical and socioeconomic factors lead to the emergence of large scale invasion patterns.  Findings of the project will help to inform forest managers, policy makers, and other stakeholders on how to better prevent and mitigate the economic and ecological damages of invasive species through multiple venues such as workshops and webinars, and online planning tools.  The project will have high impact on the education of a diverse group of students and researchers through research opportunities, mentoring, and workshops.  It will facilitate broad, long-lasting interdisciplinary and cross-institutional collaborations.  In addition, the project will contribute to greater understanding of the general phenomenon of how "things" (e.g., disease, technology) spread, thus helping to sustain the spread of benefits while limiting unintended harms to ecosystems and society that emerge from social connectivity.

The goal of this project is to determine the underlying mechanisms contributing to macroscale invasion patterns for two important taxa of invaders (plants and insect pests) in forests across the continental United States.  The project will utilize a novel cross-modeling approach by combining: (1) machine learning-based statistical models aimed at capturing key within- and cross-scale interactions and tipping points among data challenged by different spatial and temporal resolutions, and (2) Bayesian models designed to capture model and parameter uncertainties.  This project will result in improved mechanistic understanding and more robust predictions of macroscale invasion.  The proposed conceptual framework can advance the field of invasion ecology by formulating new invasion theories and consolidating various existing ones.  The project will also help advance the field of MacroSystems Biology by synthesizing and developing multidisciplinary datasets and by developing and refining a highly useful analytical tool for investigations involving many variables in which manipulative experiments would be challenging.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Biological invasions pose a major threat to forest ecosystems across the United States, resulting in significant ecosystem degradation and economic loss.  The goal of our project is to determine the underlying mechanisms contributing to macroscale invasion patterns.  By using our trait-based, scale-dependent theoretical framework, we studied the invasion of two important taxa of invaders, plants and insect pests, in forests across the continental United States.  Our overarching hypothesis is that macroscale invasion patterns are the result of complex, non-linear, and cross-scale interactions among invader, recipient system, and invasion drivers. 

The research supported by this project advanced invasion ecology and macrosystem ecology in several major areas. First, we mapped all major invasive plants and insects across the nation. All resulting data and maps are publicly available for download, facilitating invasion management and education. Second, we discovered significant relationships between the complexities of forest systems and their ability to resist invasive species. Higher species diversity and structural diversity help forest ecosystems better resist the invasion of exotic plants and pests. Third, we identified natural and socioeconomic key drivers and their impacts on macroscale invasion. We found that spatial patterns of invasion are the result of complex, nonlinear interactions among propagule introduction and sustained vectors of dispersal occurring across spatial and temporal scales. Drivers such as land use types, land use history, road networks, protection status, and population density all have a major influence on invasion patterns and processes. Fourth, we unveiled interesting traits, thresholds, and tipping points that influence macroscale invasion patterns.  For example, we found key traits that make a non-native plant invasive (vegetative reproduction and ability of long-distance dispersal), and we identified the tipping point of native tree diversity in facilitating or resisting invasive pests. Lastly, we were able to quantify the major impacts caused by exotic invasion, especially their impacts on carbon storage. We communicated this information through publicly available and easy-to-use dashboard systems.

This research has resulted in three graduate theses and 40+ journal publications, with an additional two publications in progress. The project has sponsored three workshops/symposia, 27 invited talks, and 60+ national and international presentations. The project has also supported six postdocs (two women, one minority), three graduate students (two minority women), and 10 undergraduate students (four women and two minority). Our research results were covered by several major media outlets. Our dashboard on invasive species distribution and impacts was ranked among the top 10 NSF most popular dashboards in 2023.

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2024
Modified by: Songlin Fei
